title: HMS Whitaker (K580)
text:
The second HMS "Whitaker" (K580), and the first to enter service, was a British <a href="Captain%20class%20frigate">Captain-class</a> <a href="frigate">frigate</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> in commission during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Originally constructed as a <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> <a href="Buckley-class%20destroyer%20escort">"Buckley" class</a> <a href="destroyer%20escort">destroyer escort</a>, she served in the Royal Navy from 1944 to 1945.
Construction and transfer.
The ship was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> as the unnamed U.S. Navy destroyer escort DE-571 by <a href="Bethlehem-Hingham%20Shipyard">Bethlehem-Hingham Shipyard</a>, Inc., in <a href="Hingham%2C%20Massachusetts">Hingham</a>, <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>, on 20 October 1943 and <a href="Ship%20naming%20and%20launching">launched</a> on 12 December 1943. She was transferred to the United Kingdom upon completion on 28 January 1944.
Service history.
The ship was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> into service in the Royal Navy under the command of <a href="Lieutenant">Lieutenant</a> Glynn Percy Watkin Edwards, <a href="Royal%20Navy">RN</a>, as the frigate HMS "Whitaker" (K580) on 28 January 1944 simultaneously with her transfer. She served on patrol and escort duty and operated in support of the <a href="Invasion%20of%20Normandy">invasion</a> of <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a> in the summer of 1944.
The <a href="Nazi%20Germany">German</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a> <a href="German%20submarine%20U-483">"U-483"</a> <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed "Whitaker" at 0210 hours on 1 November 1944, off <a href="Malin%20Head">Malin Head</a> on the north coast of <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a> at position . Damage control measures brought the resultant fires under control by 0320 hours but not before the ship had lost much of her <a href="Bow%20%28ship%29">bow</a> and suffered 79 dead. Towed first to <a href="Londonderry%20Port">Londonderry Port</a>, <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>, and then to <a href="Belfast">Belfast</a>, Northern Ireland, "Whitaker" was declared a <a href="constructive%20total%20loss">constructive total loss</a>, remained inactive for the rest of World War II, and was <a href="Ship%20decommissioning">decommissioned</a> in March 1945. The U.S. Navy struck her from its <a href="Naval%20Vessel%20Register">Naval Vessel Register</a> on 19 May 1945.
The Royal Navy returned "Whitaker" to the U.S. Navy on 3 December 1945.
Disposal.
After her return to the U.S. Navy, "Whitaker" remained in the United Kingdom for ultimate disposition. She was sold to John Lee of Belfast on 9 January 1947 for scrapping.
